reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Response to COVID-19 in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia of unknown etiology was reported in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. On 30 January WHO declared the outbreak of novel Coronavirus a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. Particularly, WHO raises alert of low and middle income country and the preparedness of potential outbreaks. As of 26 February 2020, a total of 82,297 cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed and 2,805 fatalities have been reported across 47 countries. There are 141 cases in Iran which shares a large border with Afghanistan. On 24 February Afghanistan’s Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) reported one suspected case had been confirmed in the western province of Hirat. The person had recently travelled from Qom, the Islamic Republic of Iran. The MoPH has declared a state of emergency in Hirat, closed It is reported that all schools are closed and and banned public gatherings banned until further notice. As of 27 February, MoPH has now reported 10 suspected cases (seven in Hirat, two in Ghor and one in Hilmand).
Globally, case fatality rate of COVID-19 stands at 2.4%. However, in Very Low Income Countries like Afghanistan where the existing health system is weak, the emergence COVID-19 will overwhelm health provision and will likely cause more fatlaity than the global case fatality rate.
There are nine priority areas that WHO plans to cover on the overall COVID-19 response. Under the AHF Reserve Allocation, the following six thematic areas are covered
1) Improved capacity at international points of entry - 12 entry points (Hamed Karzai International Airport, Balkh Airport, Kandahar airport, Ayratan border, Turkham, Sherkhan Border, Islam Qala, Spen Boldak, Badakhshan borders, Aqina border in Faryab, and Farah) 2) Strengthened surveillance and reporting systems 3) Improved case management 4) Enhanced national and regional health facilities infection prevention and control in Afghan Japan Hospital and 5 regional facilites in high prioroty areas. 5) Improved risk communication and community engagement 6) Technical assistance

title.narrative: United Nation Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS): Domestic services towards COVID-19 response and international airbridge

description.narrative: This allocation supports UNHAS in maintaining its essential air services, ability to respond to relocation requests for aid workers and provides reliable air service in support of the COVID-19 response through a) maintaining essential humanitarian domestic air services and readiness for security and medical relocation for the duration of 3 months. b) establshing an international airbridge for UNHAS users with a jet aircraft between Kabul and Doha for the duration of 3 months.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Support COVID 19 response in Shahrak-e-Sabz and Clinic Area/Shaidayee Informal Site in Herat

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention aim is to prevent and mitigate against COVID-19 transmission and impact on Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Herat province. Afghanistan already faces major gaps within its health care system and preventing the spread of COVID-19 is critical to saving lives and reducing the burden on healthcare infrastructure and recourses. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a global pandemic on March 11, 2020. As of April 7th 2020, 1.384 million cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed and 78,917 deaths have been reported across the world. In Afghanistan, Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) data indicates that 521 people across 23 provinces are confirmed to have the virus and 14 people have died. Herat remains the epicenter for the crisis with 80% of the total registered cases in the country.
Afghanistan is likely to be significantly affected due to its weak health system and limited capacity to deal with major disease outbreaks. Afghanistan’s close proximity to Iran and the high numbers of Afghan returnees from Iran, puts the country at heightened risk, with tens of thousands of people and commercial movements across the border from each day. High internal displacement, low overall vaccination rates, prevalence of comorbidity among vulnerable populations and weak health, water and sanitation infrastructure, create a context in which vulnerability to COIVID-19 transmission and infection is high. Herat province has the highest number of COVID-19 confirmed cases in Afghanistan and hosts a large IDP population. WVA is already operational in Herat IDP settlements through the existing awards. The proposed intervention will focus on three areas, 1) Active Community Screening, 2) Risk Communication and Awareness Raising and 3) Support existing health service delivery points including isolation wards and hospitals
The medical waste will be disposed in coordination with the WHO, BPHS implementing NOGO, DEWS, UNICEF and other relevant Stakeholders and make sure no medical waste remain in the area. The disposition of the waste will be done in an area outside of the residential areas recommended by DOPH to make sure this intervention has no negative impact on the environment.
WV has already coordinated with WHO help promotion focal point and Religious affairs. The 200 faith leaders will be trained upon the approval of the proposed project. WV is already working with the department of Haj and religious affairs and the selection of the 200 faith leaders will be done in coordination with the Haj and religious affairs.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing lifesaving support to minimize the risk of COVID-19 spreading in communities and schools in Nangarhar, Faryab, Balkh, Takhar and Kunduz

description.narrative:
Following its declaration as a global pandemic and its first official reported cases in country February/March 2020, Afghanistan is likely to be significantly affected by COVID-19 due to its weak health system and limited capacity to deal with major disease outbreaks, in what is already one of the most complex humanitarian crises across the globe. COVID-19 is a potentially deadly virus, especially for those who are immunocompromised and/or elderly. Due to an already strained healthcare system, infection prevention and control (IPC) measures are urgently needed in Afghanistan to prevent the spread and ultimately save lives. ACTED will provide WASH services to communities and schools in ten districts across five provinces (Maymana district in Faryab, Mazar-e-Sharif in Balkh, Kunduz and Imam Sahib in Kunduz province, Taloqan and Rostaq in Takar and Achin, Deh Bala, Dur Baba and Goshta in Nangarhar) to reduce the transmission of the virus and ultimately relieve the healthcare system from additional cases and strain, saving lives. ACTED will target 49,994 men, women, boys and girls with IPC sensitization campaigns over the media of leaflets, posters, radio broadcasts, mobile soundsystem broadcasts and mosque speaker broadcasts.
WHO promote handwashing as one of the single most effective ways to reduce the transmission of the virus. Alongside the IPC sensitization campaigns, ACTED will also install 800 portable and 180 semi-portable wash stations in areas where there are already high WASH needs and regularly top them up with soap. 3,000 of the most vulnerable households will also receive WASH Cluster-endorsed COVID kits. In addition, ACTED will also coordinate with local authorities to cover key gaps by disinfecting key and common public places.
To ensure children’s right to an education is upheld whilst also not putting them and vulnerable communities at risk of transmitting and spreading the virus, ACTED will advocate to and work with PEDs and DEDs to ensure school re-opening plans are created. Once made, ACTED will help to implement the safe re-opening in at least six schools over the five provinces. To attract children back to schools, and especially girls who are at greatest risk to not return, ACTED will construct or rehabilitate handwashing facilities plus latrines to build back better. This will be in at least six schools and reach at least 3,090 men, women, boys and girls.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: WASH Response to COVID-19 in the Western Region

description.narrative:
The first positive case of COVID-19 in Afghanistan was confirmed on 24 February by the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH). Since then, the pace of spread has grown steadily, with fears there may be a rapid increase soon, putting significant strain on the already stretched health system in the country. Preventing the spread of COVID-19 is the most critical need in Afghanistan, particularly among villages at highest risk in Herat, Badghis and Ghor Provinces.
In order to ensure that “lives are saved in the areas of highest need” (HRP Strategic Objective one), WVI proposes interventions that will provide WASH assistance to prevent community spread in priority COVID-19 districts in Herat, Badghis and Ghor Provinces. This will be done by increasing public knowledge and practices around preventative hygiene measures through the distribution of targeted COVID-19 hand washing kits and hygiene promotion over the course of four months. Hygiene promotion will focus on regular hand washing with soap at the five critical times and on returning home, in alignment with Global WASH Cluster COVID-19 messaging. Additional MoPH COVID-19 messaging on other transmission-reducing behaviors will be provided. WVI will also conduct daily chlorine disinfection of at-risk public locations to further reduce the risk of transmission.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: COVID-19 WASH response and pre-positioning in WASH Cluster prioritized districts

description.narrative:
On March 11, 2020, the WHO declared the COVID-19 outbreak a pandemic, due to the scale and spread of transmission. Afghanistan is likely to be significantly affected due to its weak health system and limited capacity to prevent the spread of the virus. Furthermore, its close proximity to Iran, a country that has been hard hit by the pandemic, puts it at heightened risk, with tens of thousands of people and commercial movements crossing the border each day. High internal displacement and a weak water and sanitation infrastructure worsen the situation. To support the efforts of the Afghan government to contain the disease and prevent further spread, the Inter-Cluster Coordination Team (ICCT) published on March 24, 2020 the COVID-19 Multi-Sector Country Plan that outlines the strategic response approach and complements wider plans by the Ministry of Public Health/ WHO. By implementing the following activities, DACAAR directly contributes to this plan and to the containment of the COVID-19 outbreak. a. DACAAR will pre-position key supplies, namely 29,400 COVID-19 Hygiene Kits. The WASH Cluster estimates that the available regular hygiene kit stock in country can last only up to April 2020 and thus there is an urgent need for replenishment. The content of the COVID-19 kits was agreed with the WASH Cluster and the other partners. Hygiene kits are issued per family of 7 members and distributed two times during the project period by WASH Cluster partners, as well as by DACAAR. Therefore the target is 14,700 families (= 102,900) individuals for hygiene kit pre-positioning. Given that this is a stockpiling project and the distribution of the supplies will be undertaken by all WASH partners, the target beneficiaries will not only be assisted by DACAAR but by all partners. DACAAR will report on the beneficiaries based on reports from WASH partners who accessed the stockpiles. In accordance with the COVID-19 Multi-Sector Country Plan on page 35, the hygiene kits will be stocked in the following 7 strategic geographical hubs: Kabul, Jalalabad city, Kandahar city Herat city Mazar-e-Sharif city Kunduz city and in Taluqan city, with the potential of being moved to locations where need is greatest. These locations are central enough to be accessed from the 41 districts that are currently considered by the WASH Cluster to be at highest risk for spreading the virus due to the volume of cross-border movement and other risk factors (see page 8 of the Country Plan). As the pandemic spreads there will be a need for WASH supplies in the entire country. DACAAR will maintain sufficient flexibility to transfer supplies among the warehouses. b. DACAAR will install 150 hand washing facilities with functional water systems assisting approximately 22,500 individuals. The initial focus is on concentrated IDP sites, nutritional centers, border entry points, health and isolation centers as needed, schools and temporary learning spaces as soon as they reopen. Furthermore, DACAAR will provide 1,000 metal buckets with taps for handwashing to families who do not have access to functional water systems or in public locations where DACAAR cannot install hand washing facilities. c. DACAAR will scale-up messaging of handwashing at the community level, as part of hygiene promotion sessions and distribute 6,000 hygiene kits to 42,000 individuals. d. DACAAR will procure 12,500 kg of chlorine and 75 chlorine sprayers and disinfect common equipment, solid waste management areas, water supply and sanitation systems in crowded at-risk public places, institutions and hotspots. If needed, the chlorine can also be used for water treatment purpose.
As agreed with the WASH Cluster, DACAAR will incorporate stocks readily available from the previous AHF stock-piling project and incorporate the items that are not expired into the hygiene kits. Items will be used on a FIFO (first in first out) method to enable supply of materials while the new procurement is ongoing.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: WASH response to COVID-19 for the most vulnerable malnourished children and their community at both nutrition center and household levels.

description.narrative:
The proposed action’s objective is to strengthen awareness and implementation of optimal COVID19-specific and general hygiene practices in local communities and health facilities at-risk or affected by COVID19 in order to contain on-going COVID19 outbreak in the targeted areas of Ghor Province.
In the already fragile country of Afghanistan with a “current coverage of WASH services including water supply infrastructure, sanitation facilities and hygiene promotion supplies already unable to adequately support basic WASH needs from conflict and natural disasters” according to the COVID19 Multi-sector Humanitarian Country Plan, the additional burden of a country-wide disease outbreak could have disastrous consequences. The first confirmed case in Afghanistan has been reported by MoPH on February 24th, in Herat province. Since then, additional provinces have been infected, with now 20 out of 34 provinces experiencing confirmed cases with a total of 484 confirmed cases according to OCHA’s last Daily Brief (9th of April). Ghor province is already particularly affected by cycles of heavy armed conflict and natural disaster like drought, heavy rain cause to flash flood and have very high needs in terms of WASH. The emergence of the COVID19 outbreak could be disastrous considering also the fragile health system in this Province.
In order to respond to the high needs identified, Action Against Hunger (AAH) will launch a WASH emergency response to the COVID19 outbreak to increase the implementation of improved hygiene practices, notably hand-washing, and, so, prevent further spread of COVID19 outbreak, both at community level and health facilities level and with a specific focus on malnourished boys and girls. This emergency response will target 58,089 persons (15,371 men, 15,998 women, 13,091 boys and 13,629 girls) and will focus on the four following districts: Ferozkoh, Shahrak, Tulak and Taiwara, of Ghor Province, that have been identified by IOM as being among the 25 districts to be prioritized for COVID19 response since they are at higher risk of being affected by COVID19 outbreak.
More specifically, the assistance will target the two following levels: - At community level, with a strong focus on strengthening the good hygiene knowledge and practices among local population, in particular women and girls due to the disproportionate impact of the outbreak, in order to reduce the potential contamination vectors, notably through extensive handwashing practices. But, since lack of access to hygiene items is one of the main bottleneck preventing handwashing (with lack of access to water), a focus is also needed on facilitating the access to hygiene items for the most vulnerable part of the population and/or the part of the population at higher risk of being contaminated and/or developing complicated symptoms (SAM/MAM children, women attending ANC/PNC, elderly individuals, individuals with chronic diseases, IDPs). In addition, since COVID19 is a new kind of disease differing from the disease the local communities are aware of and have been sensitized on (COVID19 is not a water-borne disease), it is also necessary to raise the awareness of local population and key community leaders regarding COVID19’s specificities. - At health facility level, with a strong focus on strengthening the hygiene/IPC measures and waste management systems enforced in each health facility. Doing so will allow to avoid health facilities to be become a COVID19 contamination cluster but will also allow the health facilities to continue providing lifesaving health amp nutrition services which will be even more crucial in the context of COVID19. Based on the designed program, AAH will provide support to 23 Health facilities including Provincial Hospital and Sar-miyash Hospital. Throughout the project, the required precautionary measures from MoPH and WHO guidelines, but also COVID19 Response plan, will be taken for group activities as well as for AAH’s staff.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: WASH response to COVID-19 Pandemic in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The project aims to address critical lifesaving WASH services and supplies needs of 77,000 returnees, people displaced in formal/informal Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) sites and Informal settlements on the fringes of urban areas in 19 high risk districts identified by the Government of Afghanistan’s multi-sector response plan for the COVID-19 pandemic. The programme target area was identified and established based on the recent IOM-led Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) report and OCHA update report on Population Movements (January to December 2019). UNICEF will target up to 19 districts (in 10 provinces) among the 41 recommended by the WASH Cluster for the COVID-19 response, while also having continuous consultations with the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) and WHO on the dynamic nature of disease transmission, and making the necessary and relevant adjustments to the WASH preventive response as needed.
The proposed action will promote healthy hygienic behavior through the effective use of critical WASH services and supplies. It will target returnees from Iran and Pakistan and displaced families, especially young children, women, girls, boys, the elderly and the disabled living in the IDP camps as well as informal sites and urban slums in up to 19 high risk districts. Since there are many IDPs settled in host communities and they are also in a continuous move to find the most appropriate and secure areas for their settlement, the exact number of IDPs living in host communities is constantly changing. For this reason, UNICEF will undertake a quick assessment of population numbers and site selection in close consultation with concerned government ministries and local authorities. UNICEF, as the agency of last resort for the provision of WASH services, will coordinate the response efforts, and avoid any chance of duplication to ensure an effective and efficient use the scarce resources allocated for the COVID-19 response.
This proposal is based on the WASH cluster strategy note for AHF 2nd Reserve Allocation (RA) 2020 and allocation strategy for Afghanistan and is in accordance with the national WASH cluster strategy, targets and priorities for the revised Afghanistan 2018-2021 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated lifesaving protection response to COVID- 9 covering the most vulnerable people including women, children, elderly, disabled, and survivors of sexual violence

description.narrative: DRC aims to provide a comprehensive protection response to COVID-19 in prioritized locations to determine and report on protection profiles of affected populations and sites, assess protection risks for men, women, boys, and girls, and sector specific needs. The project aims to provide a timely, coordinated and complementary intervention based on the identified protection needs. Protection will be central to all response interventions which include service mapping, safe referrals, individual protection assistance for at risk individuals, information sharing, awareness raising on fundamental rights, protection mainstreaming training to multi-sector teams alongside partners and key community stakeholders.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Child Protection/Emergency Response Project in Eastern Region

description.narrative: Since Dec.2015, Tdh had been implementing several projects with CHF funding in Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman provinces. Since the needs of the population remain high regarding COVID 19 awareness, prevention and Child Protection and since the approach regarding awareness and prevention from a Tdh project currently implemented in Herat province proved to be effective, Tdh proposes to embark on a new, COVID 19-related project. Target groups have been identified in the conflict affected population of the provinces Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman: highly affected IDPs, returnees, returned IDPs additionally, prevention and response will be provided to separated children through interim care. The project intends to strengthen the resilience of these groups by reducing vulnerabilities through access to information on CP, by addressing specific needs through community delivered life-saving psycho-social services, the establishment of a case management system (protection), awareness and prevention of COVID 19, and by strengthening protection mechanisms through Community Based Child Protection Volunteers (CBCPV) and volunteers. These activities will be delivered in order to improve the coping mechanism of children and to detect most vulnerable children in need of further assistance. The activities will be implemented by expert Tdh social worker and social animators in the districts selected. The Temporary Protection Center (TPC) will be established for unaccompanied children supporting them through interim care, family tracking, reunification, and other services in Torkham border city. The TPC will be equipped to accommodate 15 children for 24 to 48 hours. The proposed 4-months project (from 1st June 2020 to 30th September 2020) will be implemented in the Eastern provinces as follows: - Nangarhar: Mohmandara district (6 villages), Durbaba district (2 villages), Kot district (4 villages), Lalpura district (4 villages), - Kunar: Narang district (4 villages) Chawky district (4 villages), Laghman: Qarghayi district (4villages) and Mehtarlam district (4 villages). The data collected during the planning phase of this project will be shared with the clusters and OCHA regularly and, when relevant, will be shared with other partners for further support in the intervention area. The sustainability and relevancy of the proposed project will be reinforced by integrating lessons learned and impact analysis based on the assessment report. Tdh will provide PSS and lifesaving activities to those children who are at the risk of violence the above-mentioned districts.

title.narrative: CPiE response focusing on increased awareness raising, PSS and specialized services to conflict-affected children and families in Nangarhar and Kunar provinces, Afghanistan

description.narrative: Save the Children (SC) will implement a comprehensive package of Child Protection in Emergencies services, including COVID prevention and life saving interventions, in Kunar and Nangarhar Provinces targeting conflict and pandemic affected children and adolescents, internally displaced people and of the host communities (referred to as vulnerable people throughout the proposal). Given the convergence of needs, SC has chosen to target Nurgal, Khas Kunar, Sawkey, Narang and Asad Abad districts, locations in which SC will also implement Education in Emergencies (EiE) programming under another grant, in parallel, as well as Lalpoura, Momandara, Rodat, Ghanikhail districts in Nangarhar.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Population Mobility Data and Community Engagement for Informed COVID-19 Response

description.narrative:
In alignment with the WHO’s Global Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) and the Afghanistan COVID-19 Multi-Sector Humanitarian Country Plan (HCP), IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) program will contribute to the COVID-19 response in Afghanistan, by implementing the following proposed activities, which address three areas of intervention: Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE), Surveillance, and Points of Entry.
To meet the urgent need to raise awareness on COVID-19 facts, as elaborated in the Afghanistan multi-sector HCP, in coordination with MoPH, WHO, and the COVID-19 Risk Communication Working Group, DTM will capitalize upon its extensive network of 62,000 community leaders and change agents and outreach to over 11,700 villages nationwide to implement Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) activities, e.g.deliver COVID-19 IEC materials, mobilize community and religious leaders, and conduct sessions on risk awareness, infection prevention and control, and counteracting misinformation and stigma. Additionally, to inform better-targeted, evidence-based health response and recovery programming, DTM will also link mobility and surveillance data by simultaneously conducting Baseline Mobility Assessments (BMA) and Community-Based Needs Assessments (CBNA) to identify locations at potentially greater risk of cross-border transmission of COVID-19, as a result of the recent influx of Afghans returning from high-burden areas in Pakistan and Iran. Under other donor funding, DTM has already been implementing this activity in 25 provinces, since 1 March 2020. With AHF funding, DTM will extend coverage to six of the nine remaining provinces, deploying 6 DTM teams to conduct RCCE and BMA + CBNA in Kapisa (2 staff), Paktika (3 staff), Paktya (4 staff), Samangan (2 staff), Uruzgan (2 staff) and Zabul (4 staff).
In response to more frequent openings of borders to allow stranded Afghan migrants to return, DTM will leverage its well-established information systems and operational capacity to rapidly monitor and report cross-border population movements to identify destination areas at greater risk of cross-border transmission of COVID-19, which will inform better-targeted, evidence-based health response and recovery programming. Through AHF funding, DTM will implement flow monitoring at points of entry and major transit hubs, deploying four teams of 7 DTM enumerators at the four border provinces of Herat, Nimroz, Kandahar and Nangarhar. As a contingency, these teams will be mobile and responsive to any mass influx or migration abroad that may emerge in other provinces. Furthermore, as front-line responders, DTM flow monitoring teams will also support the screening of presumptive COVID-19 cases and provide essential risk awareness and infection prevention messaging, as well as identify and refer those migrants in need of immediate health care and protection assistance.
In order to better understand mobility patterns and dynamics within Afghanistan (currently non-existent), with AHF funding, DTM proposes to conduct participatory Population Mobility Mapping (PMM) exercises and Flow Monitoring, deploying teams of 9 DTM enumerators specifically in five areas of high incidence or outbreak of COVID-19. PMM aims to identify high-risk mobility corridors, communities, and Spaces of Vulnerability (SOVs) where mobile populations and local communities interact. Following a standardized methodology established by IOM’s Global Migration Health Unit (MHU), through PMM, communities and partners then jointly develop strategies, response plans, and accountability systems to strengthen of local health systems to mitigate the potential risk of spread of COVID-19 and contain potential and ongoing outbreak.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Protection Programming to Meet the Unique Needs of Women, Girls, Men and Boys during COVID-19 in Afghanistan

description.narrative: IRC will enhance the safety and dignity of those vulnerable groups most at risk of harm and rights violations as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan - namely children, women and girls, and households with heightened vulnerability - through delivery of a tailored package of Child Protection, Gender-Based Violence response and targeted cash assistance in Helmand, Herat, Laghman and Nangarhar provinces.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Protecting Afghan children during COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative:
Children are one of the most vulnerable categories in the COVID-19 pandemic, as the current crisis compounds vulnerabilities arising from chronic conflict and crises in Afghanistan. Children in Crisis is requesting $447 603 for a rapid response to improve awareness of protection risks related to the current crisis and to increase access to essential information, supplies and services for 35 400 conflict and crisis-affected communities across Balkh, Badakhshan, Herat and Kunduz provinces. Protection programmes will be implemented in Balkh, Dehdadi and Mazar districts in Balkh, Argo, Fayzabad and Kishm districts in Badakhshan, Imam Sahib and Kunduz districts in Kunduz, and Guzara, Herat, Injil and Kuhsan districts in Herat. These areas are prioritised as highest risk Herat continues to have the highest number of confirmed cases to date due to the arrival of returnees from Iran, a global hotspot for the transmission of the virus
The project promotes the physical and psychosocial protection of vulnerable conflict and crisis-affected children and their caregivers throughout the COVID-19 pandemic through (i) increasing access to life-saving, life-sustaining information that improves awareness of protection measures and mechanisms (ii) increasing access to essential supplies including health and hygiene kits and (iii) increasing access to essential services including counselling, case management and psychosocial support, as well as specialised services including interim care, case management, and family tracing and reunification for separated children. The strategic selection of these activities is intended to respond to protection risks in the immediate term, whilst increasing children and communities’ resilience to the health and humanitarian impacts of the current COVID-19 crisis.
The project uses a scaffolded intervention that intensifies support and services across categories of increasing vulnerabilities: 40 000 parents and children will receive essential life-saving, life-sustaining information 4 500 children identified as at-risk of psychosocial stress and trauma will receive mental health and psychosocial support services 400 UASC children at significant risk due to separation from caregivers will receive counselling and case management services and 500 children at severe risk of exposure to exploitation and violence will receive specialised services including interim care, case management and family tracing and reunification. The proposed project pursues a multi-sectoral approach, integration of child protection with health, hygiene and sanitation to complement existing efforts to prevent and prepare for the pandemic.
Children in Crisis [CiC] is a protection sector specialist, recognised as one of the “Top Ten NGO” actors by the Child Protection Action Network [CPAN] in 2019. Our extensive experience and expertise in protection programming – with proven approaches to working with incarcerated children – positions us to implement an intensive intervention over a three-month project period. At present, CIC also operates an Education in Emergencies intervention targeting 3500 conflict-affected children in Uruzgan under the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund approx. 20% of this intervention includes integrated protection activities that underscore our sustained commitment and capabilities in child protection. CIC will work with Coordination of Rehabilitation and Development Services for Afghanistan [CRDSA], who will cover all activities in Herat province and with War Child UK, who will administer interim care for unaccompanied children returning from Iran, through the construction of 6 containers at the Gazergah Transit Centre [GTC]. The proposed project leverages the specific experience and expertise of each partner to ensure comprehensive coverage of all proposed activities in target areas, with optimal effectiveness, efficiencies, and equitable access for affected populations.

participating-org.narrative: Coordination Of Rehabilitation amp; Development Services For Afghanistan CRDSA

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Protection of Vulnerable and at-risk children against COVID-19 through child protection interventions

description.narrative: In Afghanistan, children continue to be exposed to violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect. HRP 2020 identified that children are at high risk of psycho-social problems including stress, panic, isolation, nightmares, and other psycho-social problems children are at risk of being separated from their caregivers and in need of temporary shelter while their families are being traced and until reunification is possible. Case management is also identified as a gap to coordinate efforts to ensure that the most vulnerable children are identified and receive appropriate services in a timely manner. There is also a lack of awareness and limited access to knowledge by children and families to protect themselves from different types of violence and exploitation. THE HRP 2020 highlights the need to continue to respond to and enhance activities aimed at mitigating the risk associated with children being separated from their families children being recruited by parties to the ongoing armed conflict and families engaging in negative coping mechanisms such as child marriage, child labor and unsafe, irregular migration due to the crisis. As such, the HRP 2020 has prioritized identification and family tracing and reunification of unaccompanied minors and separated children provision of psychological first aid and community based psycho-social support case management and referral services, provision of lifesaving support such as critical household items to children due to displacement and other natural disasters. Community structures, including community-based child protection mechanisms remain weak capacity building of key actors at the national and sub-national levels is essential. Children remain in need of risk education in and out of school to enhance their protection against Explosive Ordinance (EXO) and ERW. Community awareness raising on general child protection issues and advocacy for implementing the new Child’s Rights Protection Law to ensure children are protected from violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect will be critical this year, as will targeted awareness campaigns on how to use the negative coping strategies, such as early and forced marriage and child labor, pose significant protection risks to children. Interventions targeting girls and women, including female headed households, are critical, especially the distribution of dignity kits. While SGBV remains a sensitive topic in Afghanistan, SGBV-focused community dialogues that involve all subsets of each community – women, girls, men, boys, community elders, religious and community leaders on how to prevent and respond to SGBV continue to be a critical gap. since in the current situation COVID-19 has largely effected the children in the context in which they live. Quarantine measures such as school closures and restrictions on movements can disrupt children's routine and social support networks, while also placing new stressors on parents and caregivers who may have to find new childcare options or forgo work. Stigma and discrimination related to COVID-19 may make children more vulnerable to violence and psycho-social distress. Disease control measures that do not consider the gender-specific needs and vulnerabilities of boys and girls may also increase their protection risks and lead to negative coping mechanisms such as child marriage and child labour. Children and families who are already vulnerable due to socio-economic exclusion or those who live in overcrowded settings are particularly at risk.Due to the current pandemic situation the roads and flights are not operating and reunification are required through high cost transportation means. A specific alternative modality of mobile child protection teams are required to support case management, referral, and PSS for the children The proposed project aims to support children well-being through awareness raising, interim care, family tracing, reunification and case management in Kandahar and Nimroz provinces.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Food Security support to IDPs in Nangarhar as part of COVID-19 Response in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The project will provide emergency response to the most vulnerable households (HHs) in Nangarhar who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and were already struggling to manage their minimum food requirements, it is worsened by the loss of income/earning opportunity and thus purchasing power, as a result of COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan.
Through the proposed project Oxfam and long-term strategic partner Organization for Human Welfare (OHW) will provide cash assistance to a total of 39,400 individuals (5662 HHs) in Jalalabad district of Nangarhar province to buy food items. Based on the cluster standards and the allocation strategy paper, every eligible beneficiary HHs will receive AFN 6500 (equivalent to USD90). This amount is based on the Cash Voucher Working Group (CVWG) and Food Security amp Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) recommended full basket food items for one month (calculated based on 2,100 kcal/person/day food need of an average size family and the market price of food items). Market price monitoring will be done before and after each distribution to verify the feasibility and appropriateness of the cash amount. Cash for Food was preferred by the majority of the persons interviewed during the needs assessment since the local markets are operational. The Market Assessment confirmed that access is available but limited due to the lockdown the markets are permitted to operate specific days in a week and there is supply of basic food items.
Oxfam’s interventions will be guided by the Integrated Food-Security Phase Classification (IPC) and Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) findings. As per IPC and SFSA, Nangarhar province was already in Crisis Situation (IPC3). Around 46% of the population in Nangarhar (1,237,262 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the period of April-May 2020. The prevalence is higher in the urban area as 50% of the population in Urban area of Nangarhar (210,326 individuals) are found to be at IPC 3 or above. This project will support the most food-insecure population in urban area of Nangarhar Province, Jalalabad City. FSAC identified that protracted IDPs are among the worst hit in terms of food insecurity, in the changed context of COVID-19. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting harmful coping strategies and reduce their risk of exposure to the deadly virus.
Protection will be integrated across the project cycle by raising awareness among the women and men about their rights. Women’s rights will be discussed in country context, gender-based violence (GBV) impacts, measures to mitigate GBV and ways of getting support in case of rights violation, GBV or other protection concerns. The women and men of the selected HHs will also be made aware of COVID-19 risks, prevention methods and other vital information in this regard this will be done with no additional cost except staff time. Oxfam uses the tailored awareness raising manual, which is developed based on UNFPA and GBV cluster tools and contextualized to Afghanistan and Islam. COVID-19 Awareness raising messages developed by Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) with the support of World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF in the languages of Afghanistan will be used for this purpose.
Oxfam will integrate conflict sensitivity into the action, by conducting context and conflict analysis of the target areas. This is especially important as cash assistance can work as potential flashpoint in creating new conflict or exacerbating existing tensions. The grant of USD 689,400 will save lives of 39,400 persons (USD 17.49 per person) with USD 509,580 (73.9%) of the total funding directly going towards Cash for Food.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Food assistance to the protracted IDPs affected by COVID-19 in Nangarhar

description.narrative:
Food insecurity in Afghanistan is on the rise due to continued conflict, high food prices, unemployment, and the new COVID-19 crisis, recent IPC analysis classified 4.3 million people in IPC-4 (emergency) and 9 million in IPC-3 (crises) of food insecurity.
In Nangarhar, the recent IPC analysis shows that a total of 210,326 people in urban areas are in Phase 3 (raised) and Phase 4 (emergency). and. Moreover, the last WoA assessment finding is indicating that 59% of the IDPs have poor FCS in Nangarhar, which shows the population is in emergency and need urgent food assistance.
Following the imposition of COVID-19 lockdowns resulting in a reduction in economic activities especially for the informal daily labor market and affected the capacity to recover their livelihood. The situation contributed to a steep increase in poverty leading to an alarming food insecurity situation.
Based on our assessment conducted in May 2020 in the urban areas in Nangarhar (city of Jalalabad district), clearly showed the emergency food insecurity situation and need for humanitarian assistance. The majority of the interviewed people reported that due to lockdown they lost income and do not have sufficient food. The shortage of food leads to an insufficient nutritional intake for all, and in particular for women and children. Other negative coping mechanisms push people to take loans, to sell their assets in the market for a low price, increasing their vulnerable situation, it is also possible that families marry off their daughters sooner and younger so that they have one mouth less to feed.
Through the proposed project ZOA and long-term strategic partner SHPOUL will provide unconditional cash assistance to a total of 16,700 individuals in order to help them meet their immediate food needs for 1 month. Each household will receive a one-time transfer of (6,500 AFN / 90 USD). Alongside the cash distribution, community mobilizers will visit all beneficiaries to conduct awareness training on COVID-19, and how to potentially mitigate Sexual Gender-Based Violence (SGBV), and Domestic Violence (DV) in the families, including a focus on child rights. Information leaflets will be distributed to ensure ongoing access to information. There will be special care for persons/families with special needs which will be listed separately and the team will distribute the bank cheque in their own locations. The project team also will ask this group of beneficiaries to be helped when collecting their cash from the bank. In the meantime, the team will ask the elders to assist such people when collecting their cash.
CHS and AWAAZ complaint mechanisms will be applied to be accountable to the beneficiaries and implement all activities in an accountable transparent way.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of emergency food assistance through vouchers to most vulnerable protracted IDPs in Mazar-e-Sharif

description.narrative:
The humanitarian situation in Afghanistan continues to steadily decline, characterized by the United Nations declaring that Afghanistan was a country at war in 2017, as well as Afghanistan becoming the deadliest conflict on earth in 2019 according to the Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) 2020. Approaching its 19th year of conflict, clashes between the Afghan National Army (backed by International Military Forces) and Armed Opposition Groups, continue to inflict high levels of civilian casualties and collateral damage on health and education facilities, as well as disrupting essential civilian infrastructures such as water, electricity and telecommunication systems, worsening the grave protection crisis and causing significant displacement. Additionally, lingering effects of the worst drought in decades (2018) accompanied by relentless natural disasters including floods, earthquakes, landslides and avalanches have exacerbated effects of the conflict, led to further displacement, and resulted in high multi-sector needs across the country. Populations are characterized by low resilience and high vulnerabilities and often fall into a state of acute emergency and need urgent support to meet their immediate basic needs. Within this context, food insecurity remains severe across Afghanistan, while the country is significantly affected by COVID-19. The socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is expected to have a devastating impact on people’s livelihoods. The lockdown and restrictions of mobility, will have a negative impact on both the supply chain for basic commodities as on the earning opportunities. Vulnerable people will be subjected to higher prices of food commodities, income losses, and experience reduced access to food due to supply chain disruptions and limited access to markets due to lockdown measures. Since the beginning of the outbreak of COVID-19, disrupted livelihoods and reduced income, coupled with chronic underlying poverty, have already started to further challenge families’ capacity to purchase essential food supplies. The city of Mazar-e-Sharif, as well as the whole province of Balkh, is specifically facing this worsening situation. The latest IPC analysis classifies Balkh as being currently as of April-May 2020 in Phase 3 (Crisis), and it is projected to have 40% of its urban population either in Phase 3 (Crisis) or 4 (Emergency). Through this project, ACTED will provide immediate life-saving food security assistance to 38,500 protracted IDPs (5,500 Households) in vulnerable employment status and facing significant decrease in purchasing power in Mazar-e-Sharif. ACTED will provide a full one-month food basket (6,500 AFN / 90 USD) through vouchers to most vulnerable beneficiaries who will redeem their vouchers against food items at local markets, with pre-identified shopkeepers.
In line with WHO recommended measures and MoPH’s official guidance, every activity implemented under the project will be strictly adapted in relation to COVID-19 context and mitigation measures and all staff involved will receive awareness sessions on COVID-19.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency food assistance to meet the immediate needs of COVID-19 affected IDPs in Kandahar.

description.narrative:
With the proposed six-month project, DRC seeks to deliver one-month emergency food assistance to address the immediate food needs of COVID-19 affected IDPs in urban centers of Kandahar. DRC will target 6,642 vulnerable protracted households (HHs) with an average HH size of seven (46,494 individuals) as per the national average using cash as a modality. These HHs are characterized by unstable daily wage labor, and/or other informal or irregular sources of income that have been negatively affected amid government Covid-19 related restrictions, leading to worsened purchasing power and food insecurity. As per FSAC cluster guidelines (Jan 2020), the transfer value for cash for food is $90 USD per HH, representing a full food basket for a HH size of seven individuals. DRC assessment findings (HEAT Jan-Apr 2020) show that 89% beneficiaries indicate food as their first or second preference. This in addition to: COVID-19 mitigating measures such as reduced interaction with beneficiaries, FSPs and shopkeepers the many and scattered street vendors availability and prices of goods and food items and DRC’s extensive experience of conflict and culture sensitive cash and voucher programming in the South, deem cash for food to be the safest and flexible modality in target locations. The response is also informed by previous DRC experience and analysis of programming in Kandahar, showing that direct cash transfers as opposed to other modalities and e-transfers will warrant the access and inclusion of women. This will ensure beneficiary dignity and inclusion while supporting the local economy amid COVID-19. DRC has existing framework agreements with financial service providers (FSPs) in target locations ensuring timely and efficient response.
In addition to beneficiary preference for food assistance (HEAT Jan-Apr 2020), and a one-month cash for full food basket, target beneficiaries will be guided on the composition of the recommended food items, nutritional values and availability of the items in the local markets to encourage them to meet the intended food objective. Beneficiaries will be equipped with basic COVID-19 prevention knowledge including discerning rumors from facts, and advise to pace out purchasing of food to reduce market crowds as part of the pre-distribution process through awareness raising and key messaging.
Based on consultations with the Department of Refugees and Reintegration (DoRR), the FSAC cluster at the provincial levels as well as DRC IDP mapping, and identified response gaps, the selected locations are: Police Districts 5, 7 (Mirwais Mina), 9 (Loya Wala – right), 12 (Loya Wala – left) and 15 (Haji Arab/Salo Khan Chaman). Together these locations host an estimated 19,500 IDP HHs out of which 6,642 HHs will be assisted. Due to the fluid and fragile situation related to COVID-19, DRC would like to retain the possibility to modify the modality, locations and adjust budget accordingly, should local conditions substantially change as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
DRC will apply a targeted approach to identify vulnerable displaced population HHs in line with FSAC Vulnerability Criteria such as dependency ratio sources of livelihoods and nature of income – type, regularity lack of productive assets shelter condition presence of disability or chronic disease etc.). The project will be complemented through AHF-funded protection interventions to ensure vulnerable HHs facing protection concerns and risks (including people with specific needs - PSNs, women/child/elderly headed HHs) are identified during vulnerability assessments, protection monitoring and referred to other services (DRC and other actors). DRC will also consider individuals/HHs referred by other organizations as part of this intervention.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Food assistance to ensure the resilience of farmers with fragile livelihood status and to support vulnerable IDPs and recent returnees affected by COVID-19

description.narrative:
Afghanistan faced alarmingly high levels of food insecurity even before the COVID-19 pandemic, with an estimated 36 percent of the population facing severe acute food security and in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. The COVID-19 pandemic has turned from a public health emergency into a food and livelihoods crisis. Following the imposition of lockdowns in March-April 2020 and resulting reduction in economic activities, food assistance needs are particularly acute in urban areas where vulnerable households are increasingly impacted by a lack of livelihood opportunities, reduced purchasing power and increasing food prices. Households living in informal settlements and displacement sites, who have recently experienced additional shocks such as displacement and who lack employment are especially vulnerable, including IDPs and vulnerable returnees from neighbouring Iran. In rural areas, farmers and agricultural seasonal workers unable to cultivate and harvest have seen their livelihoods plummet and are in urgent need of food assistance during the current lean season.
In response to these needs, WFP plans to use this funding to provide unconditional, nutrition-sensitive emergency assistance to vulnerable households impacted by COVID-19 through two activities:
1. Food assistance for smallholder farmers during the lean season WFP will provide emergency food assistance to seasonally food-insecure smallholder farmers in 10 targeted districts of Herat, Nimroz and Farah provinces. The selected households were intended to receive agricultural assistance for cultivation from another partner (FAO). However, as this assistance could not be provided as planned, households depleted their existing food stocks to meet their basic food needs and thus require urgent assistance during the lean season. Households’ vulnerability has been compounded by the economic consequences of COVID-19 which have been particularly severe in the western regions of the country, including substantial rises in staple food items since mid-March 2020 (national average of wheat has increased by 15 percent, wheat flour by 15 to 21 percent, rice by 4 to 7 percent, cooking oil by 22 percent, pulses by 14 percent compared to 14 March 2020, according to WFP market price monitoring data as of 5 May 2020).
With this contribution, WFP will support smallholder farming households to meet their basic food and nutrition needs during the current lean season when food stocks and employment opportunities are reduced. WFP will purchase 654.8 mt of mixed fortified food to provide a one-off half-ration food distribution to 76,468 beneficiaries (10,924 households) in the targeted districts. Each household will receive a food basket comprised of wheat flour, vegetable oil, pulses and salt designed to partially meet their food needs for one month.
2. Cash-based transfers for IDPs and vulnerable recent returnees from Iran affected by COVID-19 WFP will provide cash-based transfers to 49,000 vulnerable IDPs and recent returnees (7,000 households) in IDP sites in Herat city who are in urgent need of assistance given the ongoing lockdown and resulting disruption to livelihood opportunities caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Targeted beneficiaries are located in the IDP sites of Shahrak Sabz, Shaidayee and Kahdistan. These already-vulnerable households face rapidly deteriorating food security as a result of the lockdown and resulting loss of livelihoods. With this contribution, WFP will specifically target households that have not yet received assistance from WFP or other partners to meet their basic food needs.
Each household will receive one transfer of 6,000 AFN (approximately US$78.43). This value has been endorsed by FSAC for COVID-affected households. Providing AFN 3,000 per month, this is equivalent to approximately half the FSAC-recommended basic food basket for a family of seven, and is designed to complement household resources to meet their food needs for two months

participating-org.narrative: Services Women Relief Center for Afghanistan

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: GBV and Child Protection Emergency Response during COVID-19 Pandemic in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed project locations Kabul, Herat, Kandahar and Nangarhar provinces are extremely vulnerable and exposed to high risk of COVID-19. GBV interventions will be implemented in Herat, and Child Protection interventions in Kabul, Kandahar, Nangarhar. As currently these locations are in the level of outbreak and having high number of positive Corona Virus cases, on other hand due to COVID 19 pandemic, recently more than 200,000 of people returned from Iran and Pakistan through Herat and Nangarhar bordering provinces. It is predicted that majority of COVID-19 positive cases came from these countries. As per Islamic Relief World (IRW) recent Need Assessment indicated that ongoing COVID -19 pandemic has significantly and quickly affected the context in these provinces. In which the children and women are more victim and exposed to risks in different forms such as violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect. Mental stress among children and women has been increased due to restriction in movement and stopping social activities.
The proposed project is focusing on provision of lifesaving assistance to 69,000 individual (men- 12,530, women- 15,560, boys- 19,750, girls- 21,160) in response to GBV and child protection in COVID-19 pandemic.
The project will disseminate mass awareness on GBV, Child Protection and COVID-19 through multiple channels i.e. FM radios, IEC and BCC materials using local in local languages (Dari and Pashto). The project will establish methods to regularly and safely share accurate, timely and actionable information in consultation with GBVSC and RCCE WG. During disseminating the messages through IEC and BCC materials, project team will apply different methods of communication i.e. one to one meeting, interactive session using IEC/BCC materials and examples etc to increase awareness and promote behavior change on GBV prevention and Child Protection as well as prevent community transmission of COVID-19. The project will engage key influencers i.e. Faith Leaders, Community Leaders, and Women Leaders to motivate people individually so that the awareness messages can be reached in the remote rural areas. 3500 women and girls will be provided culture appropriate dignity kits based on selection criteria to ensure their safety and dignity. GBVSC's standard items will be followed for the dignity kits. The project will assign Mobile Outreach teams for providing Psycho-social Support (PSS) for GBV survivors women and girls. The teams will interact with the women, girls and community members following local norms, values and align with need of women and girls. Serious GBV cases will be referred to the relevant service providing agencies. On the other hand, separate Mobile Outreach Teams will be visiting the communities and door to door for providing PSS counselling to the children at risk. Recreational materials and COVID-19 specific hygiene kits will be provided to 5000 children during the PPS sessions. 600 children at risk (separated from family) will be provided protection support through interim care, family tracking, reunification, services and case management.
IRW will closely work with GBV Sub-Cluster, CPiE Sub Cluster, RCCE WG, MoPH, district and provincial level government authorities and other NGOs to manage the response collectively and avoid duplication of works/beneficiary. All interventions of this project will be implemented with consideration of dignity, respect to the beneficiaries and their informed consent. IRW will also follow “Do No Harm” principle that guide to ensure beneficiaries security and safety in the project management cycles.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Multisector Protection support to GBV survivors in the context of COVID-19 in Herat and Daikundi

description.narrative:
Oxfam proposes a structured and timely response to the increased protection needs of IDPs, returnees and host communities in Herat and Daikundi provinces of Afghanistan. Oxfam aims to assist 34,560 individuals (6,912 men 6,566 women 10,714 boys and 10,368 girls) who are severely affected by conflicts, flood, drought and COVID-19, by providing protection and Gender Based Violence (GBV) services, which include a multisector response (legal, safety, health and psychosocial) through door-to door outreach and referrals that facilitate community-based specialized services. Women and girls’ survivors are provided with dignity kits in Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), information dissemination through media broadcasts on women rights to increase awareness, GBV and case management, referral, and follow-up of protection cases.
Oxfam will adopt an integrated approach, leveraging protection activities aligned with the priorities laid out in the AHF 3rd Reserve Allocation-2020 with the eventual objective of recovery and resilience-building in the target communities. Provision of immediate protection assistance will alleviate suffering of beneficiaries in a gender sensitive manner and increase their resilience.
Considering the fact that there are other actors in the area, in collaboration with them the following areas are agreed to be covered by Oxfam: Herat Province: Injil: Sofian, Rezeshk, Doghabad, Baland Shahi, Tallab Rawashan, Maldan and Robat Qoloq. Guzara: Kawashan, Khalachan, Ghoran, Kala Gerd, Robat Sahebzada , Ziaratjah, Pol Sangi and Zahidanha. Karukh: Gaja, Zori ha, Sang Seerkob, Dehan Ghaar, Sharif Abad, Tarin Ha, Qala Haji Mamor, Qala-e-Surkha, Merza Noor, Sagari Ha , Damjoo, Armaloq , Tajikha , Darwish Ali Qasim. Herat City: PD-6 (Nowa abad), PD-7 and PD-9.
In Daikundi the following areas will be covered under this project: Miramor: Dektor Robat, Naiqul Robat, Boomshir Robat, Sangan Suflah, Arwas , Moshmay Wona Bargar, Tagab Wana Bargar. Ashtarlay: Kharbid Sufla, Khabid Aulya, Peshdaram, Taq Safid, Lorbuz, Naleej, Dahan Naleej. Sang Takht: Dahan Selbito, Gurzak, Doghor Sufla, Doghor Aulia, Shinai Qala, Dahan Ghojorbash, Seyasang Ghojurbash. Nawamish: Dasht Khair Abad, Orkhan, Awtak, Hussain Abad.
The main objectives of the project are to: save lives, alleviate suffering and protect human dignity for the most vulnerable, support people to build their resilience and increase capacity on human rights and women’s rights to reduce protection violations, and increase respect for international humanitarian law through protection services.
Oxfam’s protection program provides awareness raising as well as practical support, through Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), psychosocial, legal services, referral of beneficiaries with protection concerns to other service providers. Oxfam has achieved concrete successes in environments such as Herat and Daikundi provinces and has an established presence in these provinces. To build on this work, Oxfam will use the AHF 3rd Reserved Allocation-2020 funding to increase the scope and scale of its protection activities, and to conduct awareness raising through media broadcasting in TV/radio programming to a wider population. AHF 3rd RA 2020’s contribution to this project will support returnees, displaced and host communities to undertake protection awareness raising, and train community-based protection committees (CBPC) for sustainability of the project.
Oxfam will provide training and sensitization on International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and protection to a majority of individuals in the affected communities, in order to increase awareness on GBV risks, available referral systems and mitigation strategies. Oxfam will establish four women friendly health spaces, community dialogues and mobile community outreach, which will support protection responses in the
